page.title: 16HISTORICAL PERSPECTIVE
page.content:
Most of this area is traditionaly agricultural and sparsely populated. Two hundred years ago blame for the depopulation was attributed to"the largeness of the farms,one man renting as much land now as three or four did formerly"* The land here is rich,but, watered by two rivers,is prone to flooding.In 1790 the Gryffe rose so high and so suddenly that it"carried away complete fields of oats six miles above Inchinnan Bridge"* Many of the place-names suggest this feature:Moss Edge,"moss"being "marshy or peaty ground";Abbotsinch and Inchinnan, "inch" being "an island or low-lying ground near a river"
* "The Statistical Account of Scotland volume VII"
